content.webTitle: Mortimer & Whitehouse: Gone Fishing – a comic reflection on life, mortality and tench

fields.headline: Mortimer & Whitehouse: Gone Fishing – a comic reflection on life, mortality and tench
fields.bodyText: I remember it well. Staring at – practically hypnotised by – the float, a little orange stick in the water, willing it to twitch. And then, when it does, that magical moment, not quite believing it. Did it really happen, or did I imagine it? It twitches again, bobs down and goes under. You pick up the rod and strike. Yes! Resistance, a connection via a thin nylon thread to a fish. We’re in. It is a childhood memory: I don’t do fishing much these days, but I know that if I went again, it would come rushing back, that heart-quickening thrill, interspersed by long periods of very little. “There were so many things, Paul, that we loved and we don’t bother doing any more,” says Bob Mortimer to his friend Paul Whitehouse. “Drugs,” says Paul, quick as a flash. “Drugs, for example,” agrees Bob. Also other things, including fishing. They’re on the edge of a pond in Norfolk; Paul has brought his old pal Bob here in search of an elusive member of the carp family called a tench. Both have recently had heart ops: Paul had stents fitted, Bob a triple bypass (“A more senior operation,” he boasts). Later he shows Paul his scar, a dotted line up his front like a zipper. Bob Mortimer, human beanbag. No drugs these days, then, apart from ones that make hearts go slower and blood run thinner, perhaps. And no biscuits. “The problem is when you’ve got heart disease, as you have, and I have, you can’t just reach endlessly for biscuits, can you, for comfort?” says Paul. “Big gap in your life, when they take cheese from you, biscuits from you,” Bob replies. “What do you reach out to? A nut?” “Therapist.” “A magazine.” No tench today, either. And that’s probably no bad thing, their tickers might not stand up to the excitement of a bobbing float. And it allows them to reflect on mortality, to be funny and to be together. What historical figure would Bob’s ideal fishing companion be, Paul wonders. “I don’t know much about history,” says Bob. “What about trigonometry?” says Paul, again quick as a flash. Bob doesn’t know much about trigonometry either. No, Paul meant the song, Bob knows he did … I think Bob Mortimer’s ideal fishing companion is Paul Whitehouse. And neither is history just yet. They spend a night in a yurt. In – although not entirely convinced by – a yurt. Two yurts, in fact; there comes a time in life when you no longer have to share a yurt … Hang on, they’re not even that old: 59 (Bob) and 60 (Paul). The following day, they go and stand by another Norfolk pond, to reflect on their own mortalities and to continue their quest for tench … The float twitches, bobs, goes under. Paul grabs the rod (he’s more about the fishing; I think Bob’s really just here because Paul is). Fish on! It’s not a tench, though: they’ve caught a bream. “They’re not exactly a fighter, the bream,” says Paul. You can say that again; this miserable specimen just rolls over on to its side on the surface of the water and gives up while Paul reels it towards Bob, who’s waiting for it with his net. Neither of these boys did that, rolled over and gave up; they’re fighting on, without biscuits. Bob actually catches a couple for himself – again, not tench, though. One is a roach, a pretty little thing (with the emphasis on little); the other a rudd, also a tiddler. But at least it’s got some life in it and jumps back in on its own accord. Of course, it’s not really about the fish or the fishing. It’s about two funny people together somewhere you don’t normally see them. It is about friendship – male friendship – and getting older and reminiscing; joking about mortality and life. Not unlike The Trip, then, with Mortimer and Whitehouse in the Coogan and Brydon roles and trying to catch fish instead of eating them in restaurants. There are even impressions: Bob, who’s wearing a jacket a bit like Travis Bickle’s, does his De Niro. It’s fine until he starts talking and then it gets less like De Niro. Stick to silent De Niro, Bob (although, actually, a bad impression is funnier than a good one). It doesn’t have the same “how-much-of-this-is-real” element as The Trip; this is reality rather than hyper-reality. It’s more ambling and shambling. It doesn’t have the tension or the feeling that you are going deep into dark places in the protagonists’ souls … OK, so it’s not as good as The Trip. But then not much is. This is still lovely: warm and funny and human and healthy. And, in the end, there’s even a tench.
